creator: ferguson_1950

content: To change default, try this: - click 'account settings' - highlight the account on left side that you want to make the default. - now, click the 'account actions' menu that lies below the list of accounts and select to make default. - use the same sequence of steps for any accounts you want to delete.
creator: davidsk

content: Thanks that worked! I thought I had looked there before. My other general problem went away after I (re-)supplied one account password! And my main gmail as default.. all good. Cheers mate

content:
First, uninstalling and reinstalling is NEVER a solution unless Thunderbird itself is not functioning or menus aren't working or screens are frozen repeatedly. Second, thunderbird is designed such that reinstalling need not affect the accounts. That is, before doing anything major, you should always 1) exit thunderbird and then, 2) copy the profile elsewhere. Also, the final prompt on an uninstall is whether to delete account data. So, even if you did a reinstall, the accounts will still be there and not lost. But it's not needed. I just added that as extra info.

On your problem, it is often helpful to delete the account if it's cause setup problems. The DONE you mention just means that Thunderbird found the servers. Your individual account remains unconfirmed. I always propose omitting password during setup and waiting for the prompt for it. Posting screenshots of your incoming and outgoing settings often prove useful, so those with Yahoo experience can comment on the settings.
creator: davidsk

creator: @next

content:
I don't know what you mean by setting up for online storage, so I will assume you meant the folders were set for offline access an to sync 100% of the messages. Here are some possibilities: - click the synchronization pane - click 'advanced' button and untick all folders - change sync settings from 100% to a smaller number - also tick the box for messages above a certain size (make it small)

Since this is an IMAP account, you could also - exit thunderbird - locate the files (e.g. inbox, inbox.msf) in profile and delete them (or, if you are unsure, MOVE to another location) - tip: while there, look for any NSTMP files as they can be deleted. Look also for duplicate account setups (account names followed by -1, -2, etc.) as the NSTMP files can be immediately deleted, and the others have a possibility of having duplicates of your messages. If found you would need to review. - restart thunderbird and the folders will be repopulated.

Now, you can see whatever the savings are. This is a difficult assignment, because you still need headers of all messages so you can access as desired.
creator: davidsk

content: - click 'account settings' - if more than one account, highlight the desired account for the postal address on left side - in the box for signature, just type it in. - then, click 'composition&addressing' on left side of screen - click 'Composition' in left side - here you can specify where to place the signature and whether also for forwards or replies.

content: A quick fix would be to create a filter to mark this not junk.
creator: davidsk

content: I'd love to...but I don't see how to do that. Would you mind telling me? Thanks
creator: linda130

content: Ok, it's easier than it sounds, because the filter panes explain as you go. - click tools>message filters - at top, select the account and click the NEW button - at top, enter a name for it, whatever will remind you of its role - untick 'manually run' - click to run AFTER junk classification - set 'match any of the following' - set FROM and 'contains' and then enter enough of email address to be unique. doesn't have to be all - for actions, 1) set 'move to' and select your account's inbox and 2) set Junk to be 'not junk ' - click OK. you're done.
creator: davidsk

content:
Thanks! I did find I had the address on filter but I had "Manual filter" checked and didn't know about the "set Junk to be 'not Junk" And now I know how to do all this.... She's also on a Whitelist but that comes after all the other stuff. 

Hopefully this will solve the problem.
creator: linda130

content: There is no whitelist feature in Thunderbird. (Note: Tools>Options has been changed to Tools>Setting.) You might see if the online account is doing this, or whether the online account can whitelist it there. All I can suggest is to regularly mark as not spam. Another trick would be to create a filter for this address to mark as not junk.
creator: davidsk

content: Thanks, I will try this.
creator: dwmusic

content:
Some thoughts: - never assume that your software is moved somewhere without checking (ok, end of homily..) - if you want the profile elsewhere, i would - if profile already exists, copy to whichever drive you prefer using File Explorer -- click help>troubleshootinginformation -- scroll down to 'profiles' and click 'about:profiles' -- click 'create profile' in upper left -- click next -- enter a short name for the profile and THEN click the browse button to locate and select the profile you placed externally -- for periodic backups, exit TB and use File Explorer to copy the profile elsewhere

I defer to others about Firefox
creator: davidsk

content: My guess is your email account is exceeding quota. Contact your email provider to increase your space allocation or reduce your space usage.
creator: davidsk

content: Suggestion, and it's only that, a possibility: it may be that thunderbird is having difficulty closing files when shutting down, preventing it from keeping password for next time. I suggest viewing in File Explorer to see last update date of prefs.js file and whether there might be multiple copies. There is a possibility that some other program (antivirus?) is preventing thunderbird from saving it. I make this assumption because, once you enter the password, you are able to access the account, but not the next time.
creator: davidsk
